awd_titl_txt: Exploring Contacts in a New Era: Spin-Orbit Coupling and Dimension Crossover
awd_abstract_narration:
The pursuit of universal laws has been a long-term effort in physics. In classical mechanics, Newton's laws could explain a vast range of phenomena, including the falling of an apple from a tree and the orbiting of planets around the sun. In quantum mechanics, however, it is much more difficult to identify universal physical laws, since it is notably difficult to solve Schrodinger's equation for quantum systems composed of many interacting particles. This is unfortunate as the bulk of all systems consist of many interacting particles.  Ultracold atoms provide physicists a promising platform to reveal universal principles in the quantum world. Due to the fact that the average particle-particle spacing is much larger than the range of interactions between charge-neutral atoms, the so-called "contacts" can be used to establish a variety of potentially powerful universal relations, which are valid regardless of microscopic parameters of the ultracold atoms themselves. Such universal relations bring physicists a conceptually novel means to understand and explore quantum many-body physics. This project will explore the use of "contacts" in ultracold gases in the hope of identifying new universal relations in many-body systems. 
 
Recent experimental developments offer physicists unprecedented opportunities to study contacts and universal relations. Synthetic spin-orbit couplings have been realized in many experimental groups. These novel couplings fundamentally influence the short-range asymptotic behavior of many-body wavefunctions and are expected to produce unexplored universal relations. External trapping potentials can continuously change the dimension of a quantum system. Traditional results derived for a given dimension no longer apply in such dimensional crossovers. This project aims to use spin-orbit coupling and dimensional crossover as unique tools to explore a new era of contacts. Topics include delivering new universal relations, engineering unconventional effective Hamiltonians for creating novel few- and many-body states, and implementing contacts as a new scheme for tracing quantum many-body phenomena.  The outcome of this project will provide new insights into bridging few- and many-body physics using contacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Though quantum many-body systems exhibit very complex behaviors, simplicity may emerge from universal laws that any dilute quantum systems must obey.  This project has focused on universal relations in dilute quantum gases that are centered around contacts. Contacts characterize the probability of having two particles at short distance in any systems with a length scale separation that the range of interparticle interaction is much smaller than the average interparticle spacing.  Whereas contacts are often studied separately in different dimensions, in a realistic system, physics may involve multiple dimensions. For instance, confining atoms in quasi-one-dimensional or quasi-two-dimensional traps, scatterings between atoms are always three-dimensional like at short distance regardless of the tightness of the transverse confinement. Meanwhile, at larger distance, low-dimensional features inevitably show up in quantum systems. An intrinsic question then arises. How to establish universal relations for such dimension crossovers? 

We have found that in quasi-one-dimensional or quasi-two-dimensional traps, both three-dimensional contacts and their lower-dimensional counterparts can be defined. Whereas these contacts govern physics at different length scales, a universal relation exists among themselves. For instance, for systems with either s-wave or p-wave scatterings, three-dimensional contacts governing short-range physics are related to two-dimensional or one-dimensional contacts by a simple geometric factor. As such, physics in quasi-one-dimensional or quasi-two-dimensional traps can be characterized by either universal relations in three dimensions or lower dimensions, being the two sides of the same coin. Physical observables such as the momentum distribution thus feature crossover behaviors and intrinsic universal relations exist in such crossovers when the momentum gradually changes from one scale to the other. 

Other than one- or two-component systems, atoms could have a large internal degree of freedom. For instance, a multi-component fermonic system may have isotropic interactions between different components that provide the system with a SU(N) symmetry. Though it has been found that such fermions in one dimension could bosonize with increasing the number of components based on measurements of some specific observables, a fundamental question about bosonization of SU(N) fermions in high dimensions remained open. This project has rigorously proved bosonization of SU(N) fermions in three dimensions using contacts that approach the values of bosons in the large N limit and the prediction has been verified in experiments.  Whereas most studies of universal relations have been focusing on closed systems, this project has studied systems with losses and identified universal relations between two-body decays and many-body correlations. In addition, spin-orbit couplings have been investigated for accessing novel quantum phenomena in synthetic Hall cylinders and synthetic Hall tori. 

Outcome of this project provides us with a deep understanding of universality of quantum gases at low dimensions, as well as a new means to explore low-dimensional quantum systems. These results will also provide the condensed matter community, the nuclear physics community and the high energy community with a new perspective to explore connections between few-body and many-body physics and to study the interplay between different statistics. Universal relations in systems with losses will offer physicists and chemists a new routine to study reactions in a quantum many-body environment. The protocols to create synthetic Hall cylinders and Hall tori provides experimentalists with a new means to access novel topological phenomena using spin-orbit couplings. This project has also been used to train graduate students to learn analytical skills and useful numerical techniques in few- and many-body physics.
